quotes.topic_title: Conviction as the signal to persist or quit
quotes.text: I basically say, "How much conviction do you have in the solution you're building?"
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A simple diagnostic question founders can use to decide whether to persist, pivot, or quit.

quotes.topic_title: Conviction as the signal to persist or quit
quotes.text: Now knowing all you know, do you have more or less conviction in the problem and the solution you're building?
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A heuristic that compares current conviction (with more information) against initial conviction to guide decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Conviction as the signal to persist or quit
quotes.text: And for those people, I'm like, "You know what? You're just in the messy middle. Stick with it. This is par for the course."
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: Reframes repeated failures as a normal phase when conviction is increasing, encouraging persistence.

quotes.topic_title: Conviction as the signal to persist or quit
quotes.text: I'm like, "Then, quit. Your life is short. You have a great team. Pivot. Do something completely different."
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: Direct guidance to stop or pivot when conviction has dropped, emphasizing opportunity cost and team redeployment.

quotes.topic_title: Conviction as the signal to persist or quit
quotes.text: If you've lost conviction, you should not be doing what you're doing in the world of entrepreneurship.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A strong, memorable rule-of-thumb that challenges the default “never quit” narrative.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Scott shares his advice on how to build product sense, why you should only build half the features that you want, what it takes to build a successful consumer product.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Previews a concrete, counterintuitive product principle (build fewer features) and key practitioner-focused themes.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: And we spend a lot of time on how AI is likely to change the world of product and the world broadly.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Signals a forward-looking lens on AI’s impact that product leaders can use to anticipate shifts in strategy and execution.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: First of all, I think the biggest mistakes that teams make is they become very passionate about a solution to a problem they're trying to solve as opposed to do everything they can to develop empathy for the customer that's suffering the problem.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A practical warning against solution-first thinking, emphasizing empathy as the primary driver of good product decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And oftentimes, the empathy gives you the solution, whereas the passion you have for whatever you think the solution is might be 30 degrees off with the solution actually is.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for how teams drift off-course when they over-commit to an initial solution hypothesis.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Well, in the chief product officer role, I oversaw design, product, and engineering. And I think part of the reason I was even interested in coming into the company and taking this role is that I felt like these boundaries between these functions are at best artificial, at worst really constraining.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A leadership/operating model advocating for collapsing functional silos to improve product outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And I always have felt like a lot of products win not because of the technology but the user's experience of the technology.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A crisp principle that reframes competitive advantage around UX rather than raw technical capability.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Braintrust charges a flat rate of only 10%, unlike agency fees of up to 70% so you can make your budget go four times further.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete cost benchmark that can inform build-vs-buy and hiring-channel decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Scott’s new Adobe role and responsibilities
quotes.text: If you look back at the last five years or so, it really has been about getting our core products to the cloud, making them collaborative, making some critical and interesting opportunistic acquisitions over the years, ensuring that we have connectivity between the products that we launched, new web apps that meet new types of creatives.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A concrete, multi-pronged playbook for modernizing a product suite: cloud migration, collaboration, acquisitions, ecosystem connectivity, and new web apps for emerging users.

quotes.topic_title: Scott’s new Adobe role and responsibilities
quotes.text: Now with the advent of AI and new and emerging fast-growing businesses we have like the 3D and immersive space, the stock business and how that whole space is being changed by new technology, the idea of bringing that into an organization and being able to focus on that full-time was really exciting to me.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: Highlights a strategic trigger for role and org redesign: major platform shifts (AI) plus fast-growing adjacencies (3D/immersive, stock) warrant dedicated focus.

quotes.topic_title: Scott’s new Adobe role and responsibilities
quotes.text: Well, I think that it's the strategy of a company always needs to be iterated.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A simple operating principle for leaders: treat strategy as a continuous iteration loop, not a periodic planning artifact.

quotes.topic_title: Scott’s new Adobe role and responsibilities
quotes.text: And I have a lot of feelings about that having been an entrepreneur that went through integration myself. So it's kind of fun to be on the other side and try to improve it from that vantage point.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A practitioner lesson on M&A: use firsthand integration pain to improve how acquisitions are integrated from the acquiring side.

quotes.topic_title: Scott’s new Adobe role and responsibilities
quotes.text: On the design side, I spend a ton of time reviewing the design across every product and really trying to raise the bar for the experiences we're shipping. And that's a hard thing to do in a company that has a lot of legacy products and a lot of baggage that comes with them.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: Emphasizes a scalable quality lever—cross-product design review—while naming the real constraint: legacy-product baggage.

quotes.topic_title: Why Scott thrived as Adobe’s CPO
quotes.text: Well, in the chief product officer role, I oversaw design, product, and engineering.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: Highlights a structural lever for CPO effectiveness: owning the full triad of design, product, and engineering.

quotes.topic_title: Why Scott thrived as Adobe’s CPO
quotes.text: And I think part of the reason I was even interested in coming into the company and taking this role is that I felt like these boundaries between these functions are at best artificial, at worst really constraining.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: Offers a mental model that cross-functional boundaries are often self-imposed constraints that limit product outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Why Scott thrived as Adobe’s CPO
quotes.text: And I always have felt like a lot of products win not because of the technology but the user's experience of the technology.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A memorable principle for prioritization: competitive advantage often comes from UX, not raw tech.

quotes.topic_title: Why Scott thrived as Adobe’s CPO
quotes.text: And so, if you have an aligned team that gets that and makes decisions accordingly, I think you can ship better experiences.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: Actionable guidance that alignment around experience-driven decision-making improves shipped quality.

quotes.topic_title: Why Scott thrived as Adobe’s CPO
quotes.text: And I think that a lot of chief product officer roles traditionally don't oversee engineering and sometimes don't even oversee design. And for me, that wouldn't be interesting.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A pointed observation about role design: limited scope can cap a CPO’s ability to drive meaningful change.

quotes.topic_title: Building product sense through empathy and psychology
quotes.text: First of all, I think the biggest mistakes that teams make is they become very passionate about a solution to a problem they're trying to solve as opposed to do everything they can to develop empathy for the customer that's suffering the problem.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that product sense starts with customer empathy, not conviction in a preconceived solution.

quotes.topic_title: Building product sense through empathy and psychology
quotes.text: And oftentimes, the empathy gives you the solution, whereas the passion you have for whatever you think the solution is might be 30 degrees off with the solution actually is.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A practical heuristic for why teams should invest in empathy-building to avoid building the wrong thing.

quotes.topic_title: Building product sense through empathy and psychology
quotes.text: I talk a lot about the first mile experiences that we have across any product we use, whether we're a consumer or an enterprise user. In the first 30 seconds of using a new product, you are lazy, vain, and selfish.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A memorable framework for designing onboarding and early UX around real human behavior under time pressure.

quotes.topic_title: Building product sense through empathy and psychology
quotes.text: It's fascinating to me that most teams spend the final mile of their time building the product, considering the first mile of the customer's experience using the product.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation that teams often underinvest in onboarding/orientation despite its outsized impact on activation and retention.

quotes.topic_title: Building product sense through empathy and psychology
quotes.text: I would say it's the onboarding. It's the orientation, and it's the defaults.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A concrete checklist for what to include when improving the “first mile” experience.

quotes.topic_title: First mile remains critical as customers evolve
quotes.text: The answer is lots of opportunity. The reason is because the customers change. Every new cohort of new customers is different.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A reminder that “first mile” optimization is never done because the user base continually shifts over time.

quotes.topic_title: First mile remains critical as customers evolve
quotes.text: The new customers you have in the early stages of your product are typically more willing and forgiving customers. And you might nail the onboarding process for them, and then suddenly realize that, "Wait, it's not being as effective anymore."
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: Explains why onboarding that worked early can decay as you move beyond early adopters.

quotes.topic_title: First mile remains critical as customers evolve
quotes.text: And the reason is because now you're engaging more of those pragmatist customers, those later stage customers who are initially more skeptical, less forgiving, less willing to deal with your friction. And so, you have to reimagine the onboarding process all over again.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A practical trigger for when to redesign onboarding: when your growth brings in more skeptical, friction-intolerant cohorts.

quotes.topic_title: First mile remains critical as customers evolve
quotes.text: I mean when you look at a product like Photoshop, for example, it used to cost hundreds and hundreds of dollars. Now, ow you can get Photoshop for as little as 10 bucks a month. And so of course, the funnel's a lot larger.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A concrete example of how pricing/distribution changes expand the funnel and force onboarding to evolve.

quotes.topic_title: First mile remains critical as customers evolve
quotes.text: To this day, we've always had to generalize onboarding experiences for the most part for everyone. And I'm really excited about the day when kind of products meet us where we are based on what type of user we are.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A forward-looking model: AI enables personalized onboarding that adapts to different user types instead of one-size-fits-all flows.

quotes.topic_title: How to build empathy: shoulder-to-shoulder research
quotes.text: Well, the most humbling moments for me as a product leader have always been shoulder to shoulder to customers. Watching them actually go about their day, not just use my product but go about their day because what you end up getting is context for a lot of data that you're missing.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A concrete research method—observe customers in their full day-to-day—to uncover missing context behind the data.

quotes.topic_title: How to build empathy: shoulder-to-shoulder research
quotes.text: When customers are using your product, they're using it amidst everything else around them.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A reminder that real-world usage is embedded in competing demands, so product decisions must account for surrounding distractions and constraints.

quotes.topic_title: How to build empathy: shoulder-to-shoulder research
quotes.text: And in order to really understand where the customer is and where their mentality is, you have to understand the context in which they're using your product.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A practical principle: customer understanding requires studying the environment and mindset, not just in-product behavior.

quotes.topic_title: How to build empathy: shoulder-to-shoulder research
quotes.text: So part of developing empathy is being shoulder to shoulder and just encountering that reality alongside your customer.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: An actionable empathy-building tactic: spend time alongside customers as they work and live.

quotes.topic_title: How to build empathy: shoulder-to-shoulder research
quotes.text: And with empathy, we can then better create quote-unquote, "for ourselves" because by developing empathy for others, we're feeling what they're feeling. We can then be the customer.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A mental model for product sense: empathy enables teams to simulate being the customer and build with that intuition.

quotes.topic_title: Designing for surprise to drive word-of-mouth
quotes.text: And the other thing that perplexes me is that product leaders expect people to talk about a product being great. And people don't talk about a product doing exactly what they expected it to do. They talk about a product doing what they didn't expect.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that word-of-mouth is driven by unexpected outcomes, not meeting baseline expectations.

quotes.topic_title: Designing for surprise to drive word-of-mouth
quotes.text: People are not going and talking about how they had a great drive today, but they're talking about the Easter egg they discovered on the dashboard or the cool new feature that they discovered that is associated with Christmas or whatever.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A concrete example (Tesla Easter eggs) illustrating how surprise features become the story users share.

quotes.topic_title: Designing for surprise to drive word-of-mouth
quotes.text: why aren't we optimizing for those things that people wouldn't expect the product to do as a way to get that surprise and delight to talk about it, to develop a relationship with our products?
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: Actionable product strategy: deliberately optimize for unexpected delight to generate talkability and attachment.

quotes.topic_title: Designing for surprise to drive word-of-mouth
quotes.text: I like that, magic, sort of a little mystery, a little intrigue, a little surprise. It's a classic trick that Hollywood uses all the time. Why don't we use it in our own products?
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A memorable mental model—borrow “Hollywood” techniques (mystery/intrigue/surprise) to design product experiences people share.

quotes.topic_title: Why most new consumer apps fade quickly
quotes.text: Uber was a consumer product, but it built a network effect that was never there before. It leveraged excess capacity that was always there, but never tapped. It did something under the hood that gave it lasting power.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A durability test for consumer apps: create a new network effect and unlock latent supply/demand rather than relying on surface-level UX novelty.

quotes.topic_title: Why most new consumer apps fade quickly
quotes.text: And with that product, he had this unique insight into the consumer psychology where it was not as much about getting likes and portraying yourself through pictures of you and seeing pictures of friends and all of this sort of anxiety that is induced by that, but rather helping people collect and represent themselves with their interests.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: Points to differentiated consumer psychology (identity via interests vs. social validation) as a defensible product wedge.

quotes.topic_title: Why most new consumer apps fade quickly
quotes.text: And there was a fascinating business component which was it drove a crapload of traffic to every source of every pin, which then got those sites to then put pin buttons themselves because they wanted more traffic.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete growth loop where value to external publishers creates distribution and reinforces the network effect.

quotes.topic_title: Why most new consumer apps fade quickly
quotes.text: I think that a lot of these other more recent consumer products are just kind of clever momentary interfaces. And they are in effect at the expense of venture capitalists, R&D for the platforms that already have the network effects and already have the distribution channels and the ad sales and everything else.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A contrarian warning: many startups inadvertently prototype features for incumbents with built-in distribution advantages.

quotes.topic_title: Why most new consumer apps fade quickly
quotes.text: They're fun and novel. But if they really work, those features are then brought into the native Apple camera, for instance.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A practical risk model for consumer apps: if your differentiation is a feature, expect fast platform copying and plan defensibility accordingly.

quotes.topic_title: What consumer success requires today (vs. 10 years ago)
quotes.text: I think my answer 10 years ago would probably be different than my answer today.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: Highlights that the requirements for consumer product success have shifted materially over the last decade, implying teams must update their assumptions.

quotes.topic_title: What consumer success requires today (vs. 10 years ago)
quotes.text: Fast forward to today where all of us are far more technologically literate and we are able to manage a lot more cognitive load in our everyday technology lifestyles.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A key lens for product design today: users can handle more complexity, enabling different UX and feature strategies than in the past.

quotes.topic_title: What consumer success requires today (vs. 10 years ago)
quotes.text: And so suddenly, we don't mind five tabs. We don't mind features hidden and tucked away in menus because we're sort of used to that now.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: Actionable implication for practitioners: modern users tolerate denser, more layered interfaces, allowing consolidation of functionality.

quotes.topic_title: What consumer success requires today (vs. 10 years ago)
quotes.text: And so, maybe that's one of the reasons why these established platforms get away with basically copying any novel new capability as opposed to those becoming apps in and of themselves.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: Explains a competitive dynamic: new features are more likely to be absorbed by platforms than to sustain standalone apps.

quotes.topic_title: Build half the features: optimize for desired problems
quotes.text: I always tell them to optimize for the problems they want to have.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A simple decision rule for MVP scoping: build toward the “good” problems that only appear after users reach value.

quotes.topic_title: Build half the features: optimize for desired problems
quotes.text: Only do the things that prevent people from getting to the point where they care enough to ask you for anything.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: Practical prioritization guidance: focus on removing blockers to activation/value, not fulfilling feature requests prematurely.

quotes.topic_title: Build half the features: optimize for desired problems
quotes.text: So actually if you make the whole product about one thing, everyone does that. That core crank operates at 10X the velocity and if that's the most important metric for the business, that's gold.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A memorable model for focus: narrowing the product to one core action can dramatically accelerate the key metric.

quotes.topic_title: Build half the features: optimize for desired problems
quotes.text: For 24 hours, we had people reaching out to us being like, "Damn you. How could you take away these controls for color of portfolio?" After that 24 hours, we basically never heard about it again.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A concrete example showing that backlash to removing features is often brief, making feature pruning less risky than it feels.

quotes.topic_title: Build half the features: optimize for desired problems
quotes.text: And that's why I always feel like tough decisions almost always afterwards feel like a relief.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation that reinforces being decisive about cuts—relief is a signal you removed drag.

quotes.topic_title: AI’s impact: from workflow to flow
quotes.text: The mundane, repetitive labor you need to do to get anything done is what holds back our ingenuity. It's the friction. It's the work in workflows that wouldn't it be great if we could just have flow and no work?
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A practical framing for product builders: target AI at removing workflow friction so users can stay in a creative “flow” state.

quotes.topic_title: AI’s impact: from workflow to flow
quotes.text: And I think that that's what AI kind of does, is it gets us from workflow to flow.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for evaluating AI features: do they reduce process overhead and increase time-in-flow?

quotes.topic_title: AI’s impact: from workflow to flow
quotes.text: as engineers have become much more productive over the years, that doesn't mean that companies have wanted fewer engineers. It actually just means that they demand more of their engineers.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: Counterintuitive implication for org planning: productivity gains often expand ambition and output expectations rather than shrinking headcount.

quotes.topic_title: AI’s impact: from workflow to flow
quotes.text: Whereas computers remember like ChatGPT is basically just giving you what it would look like if, right? It's not truly finding edges that will become the center.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A useful boundary for AI strategy: rely on AI to synthesize the “center,” but invest human effort in discovering new “edges.”

quotes.topic_title: AI’s impact: from workflow to flow
quotes.text: It's actually just mining the center. And it's trying to regurgitate the center, which is also very helpful by the way.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A concrete way to position AI’s value: it excels at extracting and reusing established patterns, which can accelerate execution when paired with human originality.

quotes.topic_title: Collapsing the stack: cross-functional empowerment via AI
quotes.text: We're entering the era where we collapse the stack in every organization where instead of having to go to someone for anything, you can kind of do more things yourself.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A clear mental model for how AI reduces handoffs by enabling individuals to self-serve work that previously required other functions.

quotes.topic_title: Collapsing the stack: cross-functional empowerment via AI
quotes.text: It's very empowering to get the answer from data as opposed to having to go to a data scientist or a data analyst in the middle.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for teams to use AI to directly query and interpret data, reducing dependency on intermediaries for routine questions.

quotes.topic_title: Collapsing the stack: cross-functional empowerment via AI
quotes.text: So there's going to be far less game of operator across the organization and far more empowerment for people to dig their own rabbit holes, answer their own questions and get things done.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A practical prediction that suggests redesigning workflows around self-serve exploration and execution rather than request/response queues.

quotes.topic_title: Collapsing the stack: cross-functional empowerment via AI
quotes.text: I happen to believe that that's the advantage typically of small teams, is that they're flat. The stack is collapsed.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: Connects AI-enabled cross-functionality to the proven operating advantage of small, flat teams—useful for org design decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Collapsing the stack: cross-functional empowerment via AI
quotes.text: But I also would suggest that again, that data analyst doesn't have to answer redundant requests all day. She can spend time on thinking of other things without the boundaries of functions like we just discussed.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reframing: AI doesn’t just replace specialists; it can elevate them by removing repetitive work and expanding scope.

quotes.topic_title: How AI changes PM work: explore more possibilities
quotes.text: the greatest performers I've ever worked with, whether they're designers or product leaders, basically preserve the time to explore lots of possibilities. They call those possibilities down to fewer set. They get feedback on those. They refine them even further.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A repeatable workflow for high performance: explore broadly, narrow, get feedback, and iterate.

quotes.topic_title: How AI changes PM work: explore more possibilities
quotes.text: How much time do you have to explore the full surface area of possibility and find the best possible option.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: Reframes product/design quality as largely constrained by time available for exploration.

quotes.topic_title: How AI changes PM work: explore more possibilities
quotes.text: I actually don't use any of them, but it just gives me more surface area. It tells me the things that I wouldn't want to do, which is also good data.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: Concrete example of using AI for scenario exploration and negative signal, not for final output.

quotes.topic_title: How AI changes PM work: explore more possibilities
quotes.text: we're going to have the superpower of exploring far more surface area in far less time.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A succinct mental model for AI’s impact on PM work: accelerating breadth of discovery.

quotes.topic_title: How AI changes PM work: explore more possibilities
quotes.text: Having the designer hear these things and contribute gives them a golden gut as they are then sitting down later and going through possible interfaces to solve the problem.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: Actionable org/process advice: bring design into early research and value-prop debates to improve downstream decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Design upstream, generative tools, and the “golden gut”
quotes.text: One of my obsessions has been bringing design earlier into the process of product development.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A clear operating principle for improving product outcomes by involving design upstream rather than treating it as a downstream execution step.

quotes.topic_title: Design upstream, generative tools, and the “golden gut”
quotes.text: I just find that, again, collapsing the stack, if you will. Having the designer hear these things and contribute gives them a golden gut as they are then sitting down later and going through possible interfaces to solve the problem.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A memorable mental model (“collapsing the stack”) that links early cross-functional exposure to better downstream design judgment.

quotes.topic_title: Design upstream, generative tools, and the “golden gut”
quotes.text: I love bringing design upstream. In fact, that's probably been the cheat code of my career as a product leader, has just been disproportionately empowering design throughout the process.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: Actionable leadership advice: treat design empowerment as a leverage point across the entire product lifecycle.

quotes.topic_title: Design upstream, generative tools, and the “golden gut”
quotes.text: And so, you can imagine as you're doing edits in that as well as in other forms of design, getting kind of thumbnails of what you might be trying to accomplish and then touching them, almost like predictive text to go to the next step, to the next step, to the next step and take leaps in the creative process as opposed to incremental steps.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A concrete example and analogy (“predictive text”) for how generative tools can change workflows from incremental iteration to bigger creative jumps.

quotes.topic_title: Design upstream, generative tools, and the “golden gut”
quotes.text: Maybe even if 10% of people get confused to get 90% of people far faster through this process is a big win and a great opportunity cost trade off.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive optimization heuristic: accept some confusion if it materially reduces cognitive load and speeds the majority through a flow.

quotes.topic_title: Staying ahead with AI: play, write, and prioritize time
quotes.text: Quite simply in one word, play.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A simple, actionable directive for staying current with AI: treat experimentation as the core habit.

quotes.topic_title: Staying ahead with AI: play, write, and prioritize time
quotes.text: The risk of becoming more experienced in your career is you get stuck in your ways.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that seniority can reduce adaptability unless you deliberately keep experimenting.

quotes.topic_title: Staying ahead with AI: play, write, and prioritize time
quotes.text: Make sure you try it. Make sure you play with it. Write poems for your friends. Try a lot of these various generative AI tools out there just to see what's possible and pursue every curiosity.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: Concrete examples of low-stakes practice that builds intuition for what AI can do.

quotes.topic_title: Staying ahead with AI: play, write, and prioritize time
quotes.text: And capturing those things, I think, the thing I've kind of learned over the years with writing and also with product development is sometimes you capture these little glimpses and things or sketches, and they become relevant years later.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A mental model for writing (and product discovery) as building an idea inventory that compounds over time.

quotes.topic_title: Staying ahead with AI: play, write, and prioritize time
quotes.text: Listen, there's no hack to it other than ruthlessness of time and prioritization saying no to most things.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A blunt methodology for making space to learn/write: prioritize aggressively rather than searching for productivity tricks.

quotes.topic_title: Surviving the messy middle: progress narratives and micro-goals
quotes.text: When you're in those lows, you need to find a way to endure them. You need to endure the anonymity and uncertainty and anxiety.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A practical reframing of the messy middle as an endurance challenge—specifically against anonymity and uncertainty.

quotes.topic_title: Surviving the messy middle: progress narratives and micro-goals
quotes.text: I always like to remind myself that the life expectancy of humans a hundred plus years ago was 25 years old. So the idea of spending three to five years of your life on something, especially if it might fail, was a bad decision. And I think biologically, we feel the need for constant rewards and affirmation to stick with something long enough.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive biological explanation for why long, uncertain projects feel so hard—and why teams crave frequent affirmation.

quotes.topic_title: Surviving the messy middle: progress narratives and micro-goals
quotes.text: I think part of it is short-circuiting the reward system, finding micro goals and milestones that are mutually agreed upon. We're going to celebrate these even though in the greater scheme of things, they don't matter much.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A concrete methodology for sustaining motivation: define and celebrate shared micro-milestones even if they’re “small.”

quotes.topic_title: Surviving the messy middle: progress narratives and micro-goals
quotes.text: I always like to use the analogy of we're driving our teams across country as product leaders with the windows blacked out in the backseat and everyone's sitting in the backseat. And so, if they don't know what we're doing that we're making progress, this traffic is clearing, we just cross state lines. If they don't receive the narrative, they will go stir-crazy.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for why teams need an explicit progress narrative to avoid demoralization during uncertainty.

quotes.topic_title: Surviving the messy middle: progress narratives and micro-goals
quotes.text: And so there's a lot of research around progress, be getting progress and how progress is a source of motivation. And so as product leaders, we have to merchandise progress. We have to be the steward of this narrative.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: Actionable leadership guidance: proactively “merchandise progress” to create momentum and motivation.

quotes.topic_title: When to quit: conviction check for founders
quotes.text: I basically say, and I really ask, "How much conviction do you have in the solution you're building?"
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A simple diagnostic question founders can use to decide whether to persist or move on.

quotes.topic_title: When to quit: conviction check for founders
quotes.text: Now, knowing all you know, do you have more or less conviction in the problem and the solution you're building?
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A “conviction delta” check that forces an updated decision based on current information, not past optimism.

quotes.topic_title: When to quit: conviction check for founders
quotes.text: And for those people, I'm like, "You know what? You're just in the messy middle. Stick with it. This is par for the course."
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: Reframes repeated setbacks as a normal phase when conviction remains high, encouraging persistence.

quotes.topic_title: When to quit: conviction check for founders
quotes.text: But oftentimes, I'll hear, "Honestly, if I knew then what I know now, I would not have done this. Holy shit. " I'm like, "Then quit."
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: A clear, countercultural rule: if you wouldn’t start again with today’s knowledge, it’s time to stop.

quotes.topic_title: When to quit: conviction check for founders
quotes.text: Your life is short. You have a great team. Pivot. Do something completely different. If you've lost conviction, you should not be doing what you're doing in the world of entrepreneurship.
quotes.speaker: Scott Belsky
quotes.context: Encourages decisive quitting/pivoting as a rational choice when belief is gone, rather than “never quit” dogma.
